prompt: <description>Part 1 Construct a rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom, slightly tapered towards the ends. The height of the model is approximately three times the width. The model is centered in the image. 1. Create a new coordinate system. Set the Euler angles to [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and the translation vector to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. 2. Draw the 2D sketch on the X-Y plane. * Begin with face_1. + Create loop_1. - Draw line_1 from the point (0.0, 0.0) to the point (0.75, 0.0). - Draw line_2 from the point (0.75, 0.0) to the point (0.75, 0.1125). - Draw line_3 from the point (0.75, 0.1125) to the point (0.0, 0.1125). - Draw line_4 from the point (0.0, 0.1125) to the point (0.0, 0.0). 3. Scale the 2D sketch using a factor of 0.75. 4. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the coordinate system properties (euler angles and translation vector as provided). 5. Extrude the 2D sketch by 0.0141 units in the opposite direction of the normal. Part 2 Construct a smaller rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom, centered in the X direction and placed near the bottom of the larger prism. 1. Create a new coordinate system. Set the Euler angles to [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and the translation vector to [0.225, 0.0, 0.0187]. 2. Draw the 2D sketch on the X-Y plane. * Begin with face_1. + Create loop_1. - Draw line_1 from the point (0.0, 0.0) to the point (0.3, 0.0). - Draw line_2 from the point (0.3, 0.0) to the point (0.3, 0.075). - Draw line_3 from the point (0.3, 0.075) to the point (0.0, 0.075). - Draw line_4 from the point (0.0, 0.075) to the point (0.0, 0.0). 3. Scale the 2D sketch using a factor of 0.3. 4. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the coordinate system properties (euler angles and translation vector as provided). 5. Extrude the 2D sketch by 0.0141 units in the opposite direction of the normal. 6. Perform a "cut" boolean operation with the current prism (part_2) against part_1, the larger prism. The final CAD shape should resemble a rectangular prism with a cylindrical hole in the center. The prism is slightly taller than it is wide. The hole is slightly shorter than it is wide, and is centered in the wider dimension of the rectangular prism. The prism is also slightly longer than the height of the cylindrical hole. The part dimensions are: * For Part_1: length = 0.75, width = 0.014, height = 0.75 * For Part_2: length = 0.3, width = 0.0141, height = 0.3</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Three-Dimensional Rectangular Prism The first part to construct is a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The front face is angled at 45 degrees from the top and bottom faces. The side faces are parallel to each other and perpendicular to the top and bottom faces. The object has a flat base and a flat top with dimensions of 10 units in length, 5 units in width, and 3 units in height, centered on a white background. To create this part, we'll be using the given "CAD Assembly JSON" as a starting point. The part consists of a single extrusion based on the 2D sketch. Let's begin by creating a new coordinate system with the given Euler angles and translation vector. Coordinate System 1. Create a new coordinate system with the following properties: - Euler Angles: [ -90.0, 0.0, -90.0 ] - Translation Vector: [ 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 ] Sketch Now, we'll create the 2D sketch based on the coordinate system we just set up. The sketch consists of a single face (face_1) and a loop (loop_1) that contains six lines. 1. Create a new sketch on the XY plane of the coordinate system. 2. Draw the following lines (line_1 to line_6) in sequence to form a hexagon: - line_1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.6, 0.0] - line_2: Start Point [0.6, 0.0], End Point [0.6, 0.75] - line_3: Start Point [0.6, 0.75], End Point [0.3, 0.75] - line_4: Start Point [0.3, 0.75], End Point [0.3, 0.3] - line_5: Start Point [0.3, 0.3], End Point [0.0, 0.3] - line_6: Start Point [0.0, 0.3], End Point [0.0, 0.0] Extrusion Finally, extrude the 2D sketch to create the 3D model. 1. Set the extrusion depth to 0.6 units along the normal of the sketch plane. 2. Scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. With these instructions, the junior CAD designer should be able to generate a parametric 3D CAD model representing the first part—a three-dimensional rectangular prism. The final object should have a flat top and bottom with a front face angled at 45 degrees and dimensions of 10 units in length, 5 units in width, and 3 units in height, as described in the "final_shape" property of the JSON.</description>
